definition: Sima Yan (236-290), founding emperor of Jin dynasty 晋 after the Three Kingdoms period, reigned 265-290 as Emperor Wu of Jin 晉武帝
to take charge of/to manage/department (under a ministry)
surname Si
horse/CL:匹[pi3]/horse or cavalry piece in Chinese chess/knight in Western chess

sentences.english: So Emperor Wudi made up his  mind, and appointed Du Yu the Grand General for Conquering the south .
sentences.chinese: 于是司马炎就下了决心，任命杜预作征南大将军。

definition: Sima Zhao (211-265), military general and statesman of Cao Wei 曹魏[Cao2 Wei4]
Cao Pi (187-226), second son of Cao Cao 曹操, king then emperor of Cao Wei 曹魏 from 220, ruled as Emperor Wen 魏文帝, also a noted calligrapher
Emperor Xian of Han (181-234), the final Han emperor, set up by Dong Zhuo 董卓, reigned 189-220, forced to abdicate 220 by Cao Pi 曹丕
Emperor Hui of Jin (259-307), personal name 司馬衷|司马衷[Si1 ma3 Zhong1], 2nd emperor of Jin Dynasty 晉朝|晋朝[Jin4 chao2], reigned 290-307
Emperor Ling of Han (156-189), reigned from 168 to 189
Cao Pi 曹丕, emperor of Wei 220-226
Cao Wei, the most powerful of the Three Kingdoms, established as a dynasty in 220 by Cao Pi 曹丕, son of Cao Cao, replaced by Jin dynasty in 265
Jin Dynasty (265-420)
Emperor Xuan (91-48 BC) of the Former Han Dynasty, reigned 74-48 BC
first Sui emperor (541-604) Yang Jian (541-604), reigned 581-604
first Sui emperor Yang Jian (541-604), reigned 581-604
Sima Yi (179-251), warlord under Cao Cao and subsequently founder of the Jin dynasty
Liu Chan 劉禪|刘禅 (207-271), son of Liu Bei, reigned as Shu Han emperor 233-263
Sun Quan (reigned 222-252), southern warlord and king of state of Wu 吳|吴 in the Three Kingdoms period
Western Jin dynasty (265-316)
Wang Dun (266-324), powerful general of Jin dynasty and brother of civil official Wang Dao 王導|王导, subsequently rebellious warlord 322-324
